awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EaSM 2: Stochastic Simulation and Decadal Prediction of Large-Scale Climate
awd_abstract_narration:
Under this project, large-scale, low-frequency modes (LFMs) will be studied in observations and simulations of state-of-the-art general circulation models (GCMs) of Earth's climate. This project will build on previous NSF- and DOE-funded work on LFMs arising from the ocean's wind-driven and overturning circulations in the Atlantic and Pacific sectors, as well as from their interactions with the atmosphere and tropical climate variability. This project will focus on: (a) improving current understanding of LFMs and interactions between them; (b) developing, revising and testing statistical methods for probabilistic decadal prediction based on these modes; and (c) using these decadal predictions in conjunction with observations and GCM simulations to gain insight into the dynamical causes of climate change and climate variability at decadal and longer time scales. This project will continue the identification of decadal modes in the Atlantic and Pacific, from both observations and the simulations from the two most recent international climate intercomparison modeling projects, using advanced, data-adaptive spectral methods. These methods will include multi-channel singular spectrum analysis (MSSA), as well as harmonic Koopman analysis (HKA), along with stochastic modeling based on empirical model reduction (EMR). The investigators will further apply novel methods for the study of synchronized chaotic oscillators developed at UCLA and UWM, to gain additional understanding of decadal-scale teleconnections within the Pacific and between the Atlantic and the Pacific, as well as their relationships with the El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO). Using the LFMs studied in the first part of the project, the investigators will examine their decadal predictability and assess the skill of retrospective decadal forecasts made with our new empirical forecast models based on EMR, MSSA and HKA. These empirical forecasts will be compared against the initialized climate predictions being made as part of the IPCC's 5th Assessment Report. This comparison will help quantify potential skill due to intrinsic decadal modes and their interactions with ENSO, as well as with climate change. The combination of these activities will lead to advanced stochastic simulation tools for creating benchmark scenarios of future climate, based on a combination of observed data and the most robust and predictable elements of near-term climate change and climate variability, out to about 2050.

The intellectual merit of this project is in developing versatile statistical tools and methodologies for climate prediction and the validation of dynamical climate models. The project will also advance our understanding of global coupling between prominent large-scale low-frequency modes. An expected outcome of the project is improved estimates of reliability of climate projections, by developing and testing novel metrics - associated with coupling and synchronization between multiple LFMs across the globe - for validating climate model predictions.

The project's broader impacts lie in addressing a problem of utmost societal importance, i.e., understanding climate variability and change. The project's investigators are committed to making their stochastic simulations easily available to the climate community. This work will foster scientific partnerships between UCLA and UWM, and further the development of graduate curricula in climate dynamics at both institutions. The principal investigators will broadly disseminate the results by means of a dedicated web site, refereed publications, seminars and presentations at national and international meetings.

por.por_cntn:
Dynamical analysis of various Earth climatic phenomena typically involves a set of elaborate multiple simulations of the global circulation climate models (GCMs). These simulations are, however, computationally expensive, and their interpretation is hindered due to incomplete or imperfect parameterizations of the unresolved physical processes. Moreover, while detailed weather prediction out to a few days requires high numerical resolution, both theoretical and data-based work has shown that climate variability on both larger and longer scales can be represented and predicted with a substantially smaller number of degrees of freedom. An alternative approach to climate diagnosis and prediction is based on empirical modeling under the assumption it can be described as a spatially extended stochastic process by inverse modeling techniques. 

This project developed new data-driven stochastic techniques for low-order dimensional modeling (LOM). Data — whether observations or GCM output — are used to estimate both the model’s low-order, deterministic part and its driving noise. Development of data-driven LOMs can be cast as a closure problem to identify, simulate and predict macroscopic, i.e. large-in-space and slow-in-time climate modes. The key steps in LOM development are proper modeling of (i) linear and nonlinear interactions between the identified macroscopic modes and (ii) the interactions between the macroscopic modes and the much larger number of hidden ones that are not explicitly included in LOM and representing the unobserved small-scale processes. 

The major methodological outcomes of the project include: 

1.  Multilayer Stochastic Model (MSM) framework introduced by Kondrashov et al. [2015] emphasizes the ubiquitous role of the triad of nonlinear, stochastic and memory effects of data-driven closure models for high-dimensional nonlinear complex systems. The MSM framework establishes, in a data-driven context, clear connection with the Mori-Zwanzig (MZ) formalism of statistical physics, i.e. a closed system of equations for a subset of the (original) system’s variables consists of a Markovian, a non-Markovian (i.e. memory) and stochastic noise terms. The major methodological problem is that in a nonlinear climate system there is typically a continuum of scales, from the fastest and shortest to the slowest and longest. However, the layered structure of an MSM allows for an approximation and efficient estimation by multiple regression techniques of the Markovian terms as well as memory and noise terms in the absence of scale separation. The MSM approach thus generalizes various multilevel regression inverse models including Empirical Model Reduction (EMR) approach that has proven highly useful and competitive as statistical modeling and prediction benchmarks against physics-based GCMs. 

2. Chekroun and Kondrashov [2017] have developed novel Data-adaptive Harmonic Decomposition (DAH) and Multilayer Stuart-Landau modeling (MSLM) closure framework based on semigroup and integral operator theory applied to time-lagged correlation functions in space. This framework allows to reduce data-driven modeling effort to frequency-based MSM models of coupled multilayer Stuart-Landau stochastic oscillators with a very few coefficients to estimate. 

Stochastic modeling and summertime prediction of Arctic sea ice 

Kondrashov et al. [2017] successfully applied DAH-MSLM approach to Arctic Sea Ice. In particular, it provided very accurate real-time prediction of September Sea Ice Extent (SIE) within the 2016 Sea Ice Outlook – summertime forecasts by ensemble of dynamical and statistical models. The multimodel-median 2016 SIO estimate was 4.4 106 km2, while the real-time DAH-MSLM prediction was 4.79 106 km2. vs. the actual observed value of 4.72 106 km2 (https://www.arcus.org/sipn/sea-ice-outlook/2016/post-season). 

Data-driven ENSO modeling and prediction 

Chen et al. [2016] conducted a comprehensive suite of EMR experiments on GFDL model simulations to advance the understanding of ENSO diversity, nonlinearity, seasonality and the effects of memory in the simulation and prediction of tropical Pacific sea surface temperature (SST) anomalies. The results show that multilevel EMR models with SST history information improve the ENSO prediction skill dramatically. 

Interannual climate variability in the North Atlantic 

Groth et al. [2016] have identified significant interannual 7-8yr climate modes along the Gulf Stream front and in large regions of the North Atlantic in the Simple Ocean Data Analysis (SODA) reanalysis, and provided attribution to dynamical mechanisms of these modes to either atmospheric forcing or intrinsic ocean dynamics. 

Stochastic modeling of decadal variability in ocean gyres

 Kondrashov and Berloff [2015] have shown that time-lagged basis of multi-channel Singular Spectrum Analysis (M-SSA) and linear implementation of MSM closure model suffice to reproduce the main statistical properties of the decadal variability in quasigeostrophic midlatitude model of wind-driven ocean gyres. 

"Past-Noise Forecasting" (PNF) of Madden-Julian Oscillation

 Kondrashov et al. [2013] have showcased PNF methodology in EMR-MJO model that allowed to improve forecasts when started from weak MJO conditions, as well as that start over the Indian Ocean. 

New software data-driven tools developed in this project have been made publicly available for academic community at PI's website. These tools can be useful in other scientific disciplines where first-principles models are complex and nonlinear, have many uncertain parameters and require coupling of different modules over a large range of scales.
